origin_history: Seeds planted on Nov 12, 2025 in the left section.
Shares the window box with Scotch Bonnet and Orange Cal Wonder.
whats_been_logged: The plant has progressed from early emergence into steady true-leaf development, with attention focused on stabilizing moisture and pH after oversaturation. Monitoring has emphasized the vigor of the seedling cluster, the resolution of early pest activity, and improvements in soil structure as the plant transitions into active vegetative growth.
current_state: The seedlings are vigorous and upright, with bright green foliage and expanding true leaves that show strong early growth. Soil texture is improved and well-aerated following recent adjustments, and no new pest damage is visible. Overall growth appears stable and robust as the plants enter early vegetative development.

timeline.what_i_should_see: Early vegetative growth (stem thickening and new leaf production)
Ripening window (color shift from green to red)

journal.conditions: Sunny with a high of 82°F dropping to 66°F overnight.
journal.observations: The jalapeño cluster is upright and actively expanding with evenly lengthening stems and broadening leaves. Foliage remains uniformly light green without wilting or distortion. Soil surface appears evenly moist with good structure and no crusting or pooling.
journal.actions: Do not water or fertilize today. Allow the soil to continue drying naturally under full sun.
journal.next_steps: Recheck probe readings tomorrow morning or early afternoon. Plan to water once moisture reaches 40–45. Prepare for a light feeding once fertility drops below 10.

photos.caption: Overhead view showing uniform leaf expansion and improving canopy density.
Side view highlighting upright stems and healthy early vegetative structure.
Angled view of the planter showing evenly moist soil and stable plant posture.

journal.conditions: Patchy fog before 8 AM, otherwise partly sunny with a high near 84°F dropping to around 61°F overnight.
journal.observations: The jalapeño cluster shows improved vigor with larger leaves, upright stems, and a slightly deeper green coloration compared to previous days. Growth is uniform across the planter, and no wilting or structural stress is present. A few small cosmetic leaf spots are visible on older leaves, consistent with recent weather stress rather than disease. Soil remains moderately moist and stable.
journal.actions: Do not water or fertilize today. Allow the soil to continue drying naturally through tonight and tomorrow.
journal.next_steps: Recheck moisture late morning or early afternoon tomorrow. Plan to water only if moisture drops to 40–45. Monitor fertility trend before scheduling any feeding.

photos.caption: Wide view of the jalapeño cluster showing upright posture and active vegetative growth.
Overhead view highlighting increased canopy density and uniform leaf expansion.
Close-up of foliage showing healthy leaf structure with minor cosmetic spotting on older leaves.

journal.conditions: Partly sunny with a high of 83°F dropping to 67°F overnight.
journal.observations: The jalapeño plants remain upright and actively growing with expanding leaves and no wilting despite morning rain. Foliage color is lighter green overall, consistent with temporary nutrient lockout rather than stress. Soil is visibly wet following steady rainfall from early morning through mid-morning, and drainage appears adequate.
journal.actions: Do not water or fertilize today. Allow soil to drain and dry naturally to rebalance pH and nutrient availability.
journal.next_steps: Recheck probe readings once moisture drops below 50.00. Monitor leaf color for improvement as pH stabilizes. Delay any corrective action unless low pH persists after dry-down.

photos.caption: Wide view of the jalapeño cluster after morning rain showing upright posture and evenly expanding foliage.
Overhead view highlighting canopy density and lighter green foliage associated with temporary nutrient lockout.

journal.conditions: Mostly sunny with a high near 80°F dropping to around 65°F overnight.
journal.observations: The jalapeño seedlings remain upright and actively growing with expanding leaves and healthy structure. Foliage color is lighter green overall, consistent with declining fertility rather than stress. Soil surface had crusted from yesterday’s wind, making probe insertion difficult; after readings were taken, the surface was fluffed to restore aeration and infiltration. No pest damage or wilting is visible.
journal.actions: Do not water today unless rain bypasses the planter entirely. Allow natural rainfall and restored soil aeration to rebalance moisture. No fertilizer is applied today.
journal.next_steps: Recheck moisture and fertility within 24–48 hours after rain. Plan a light feeding once moisture stabilizes and fertility remains below 10.0. Continue monitoring canopy color and density.

photos.caption: Wide view of the jalapeño cluster showing upright posture and evenly expanding leaves after wind exposure.
Side view highlighting healthy stem structure and lighter green foliage associated with declining fertility.
Overhead view showing canopy density and improved soil surface texture after light fluffing.

journal.conditions: A 20 percent chance of showers and thunderstorms, partly sunny with a high of 81°F dropping to 63°F overnight.
journal.observations: The jalapeño seedlings continue strong vegetative expansion with noticeably larger leaves and upright, sturdy stems. Foliage color is slightly lighter green but uniform, with no signs of pest damage or wilting. Soil moisture has settled into an ideal range following recent rain, and surface texture appears well aerated.
journal.actions: Do not water today. Allow wind and sun to continue drying the soil naturally. No fertilizer is applied at this time.
journal.next_steps: Recheck moisture and fertility in 24–48 hours after dry-down completes. Consider light feeding if fertility drops below 10.0. Continue monitoring canopy density and stem strength.

photos.caption: Wide view of the jalapeño cluster showing expanded leaf size and upright early vegetative growth.
Overhead view highlighting increasing canopy density and uniform leaf development.
Angled side view showing healthy stem posture and improved soil surface aeration.

journal.conditions: Showers likely with a high of 81°F dropping to 63°F overnight.
journal.observations: The jalapeño seedlings show clear vegetative momentum with larger, well-spread leaves and upright posture across the cluster. Foliage color is healthy and uniform with no visible pest damage or stress. Soil is visibly saturated from recent weather but drainage appears adequate and the plants are responding positively.
journal.actions: Do not water today. Allow excess moisture to dissipate naturally through drainage and evaporation.
journal.next_steps: Recheck moisture after tomorrow’s cooler, drier conditions. Resume watering only if moisture drops below 45.00. Continue monitoring canopy density as growth accelerates.

photos.caption: Wide view of the jalapeño cluster showing increased leaf size, upright posture, and dense early vegetative growth.
Closer view of the jalapeño foliage showing healthy green coloration, smooth leaf surfaces, and active expansion.

journal.conditions: Mostly sunny with a high of 79°F dropping to 62°F overnight. Tonight: Partly cloudy. Tomorrow: Clouds and sunshine with a high of 81°F.
journal.observations: The seedlings are still vigorous, with bright green foliage and expanding true leaves. No visible pest damage. Soil moisture is moderate, and the plant's posture remains strong and healthy.
journal.actions: Do not water today. Continue to inspect leaves closely for any new chew marks. No additional pest treatment is needed unless fresh damage appears.
journal.next_steps: Check again tomorrow morning for any new chew marks or stem damage. Recheck moisture at the next morning window and only consider watering if moisture drops below 40.00.
journal.q_and_a_summary: Discussed whether tonight’s low temperature is concerning; confirmed 53°F is cool but not dangerous for jalapeño seedlings and may only slow growth slightly overnight.

photos.caption: Wide view of the jalapeño seedlings in the planter showing overall posture and soil surface condition.
Closer view of the seedling cluster showing leaf color, structure, and minor chew marks on a few leaves.

journal.conditions: Mostly Sunny with a high of 73°F dropping to 53°F overnight.
journal.observations: The seedlings are upright and stable with expanding true leaves and no visible wilting. A few leaves show small chew marks that appear older, with no obvious fresh feeding patterns visible in today’s photos. Overall color is a lighter green but growth posture remains strong and consistent.
journal.actions: Do not water today. Continue to inspect leaves closely for any new chew marks. No additional pest treatment is needed unless fresh damage appears.
journal.next_steps: Check again tomorrow morning for any new chew marks or stem damage. Recheck moisture at the next morning window and only consider watering if moisture drops below 40.00.
journal.q_and_a_summary: Discussed whether tonight’s low temperature is concerning; confirmed 53°F is cool but not dangerous for jalapeño seedlings and may only slow growth slightly overnight.

photos.caption: Wide view of the jalapeño seedlings in the planter showing overall posture and soil surface condition.
Closer view of the seedling cluster showing leaf color, structure, and minor chew marks on a few leaves.
Overhead view showing canopy density and general leaf condition across the cluster.

journal.conditions: Mostly Sunny with a high of 77°F dropping to 52°F overnight.
journal.observations: Seedlings appear vibrant and healthy with bright green, upright foliage and expanding true leaves. Dew is present on the leaf surfaces and soil but shows no sign of splash or damage. Soil moisture is finally trending downward toward a healthier mid-range. A small chewing mark is visible on one older leaf, consistent with past minor pest activity, but no new damage is evident across the cluster.
journal.actions: Do not water today. No pest control is needed at this time. Monitor leaf surfaces again tomorrow for any new chewing marks.
journal.next_steps: Recheck the cluster tomorrow morning for any fresh chew marks or new signs of pest activity. Continue monitoring moisture as the soil dries naturally under sunny conditions.
journal.q_and_a_summary: Discussed monitoring an old chewing mark and confirmed that we will check for any new damage tomorrow.

photos.caption: Morning view of Jalapeño seedlings with dew-covered leaves showing bright color and upright growth.
Side view of the seedling cluster showing healthy posture and true leaf expansion.
Overhead view of the Jalapeño seedlings with consistent color and no new visible pest damage.

journal.conditions: Slight Chance T-storms then Showers Likely with a high of 83°F dropping to 63°F overnight.
journal.observations: Seedlings appear exceptionally vigorous with upright posture, bright green foliage, and steady true leaf expansion. No new chewing damage is visible. The soil remains wet from recent rain, and the surface texture shows the effects of your light fluffing and added Miracle-Gro Moisture Control Potting Mix, which has improved aeration without disturbing the cluster. The pH has risen into an ideal range for peppers, and overall growth momentum is strong.
journal.actions: Do not water today. Allow rain and natural humidity to maintain moisture. No pest control or amendments are needed at this time.
journal.next_steps: Recheck moisture tomorrow as cooler temperatures will slow drying. Continue monitoring for steady leaf expansion and stable color. Avoid thinning until seedlings develop larger, more defined foliage.
follow_up: [7:45 AM] Filled in the probe hole, fluffed the soil lightly, and added a small amount of Miracle-Gro Moisture Control Potting Mix.

[4:38 PM] Sprayed Captain Jack’s DeadBug lightly across the entire window box at soil level to eliminate or expose any cutworms that may have dropped into the soil and to prevent potential nighttime stem damage to cilantro and the other herbs.

photos.caption: Digital probe screenshot showing today's balanced readings with ideal pH and stable moisture.
Jalapeño seedlings showing bright green foliage, upright posture, and continued true leaf development.
Side view of the Jalapeño cluster with improved soil aeration after light fluffing and added potting mix.
Overhead view showing dense but healthy cluster growth and evenly expanding true leaves.

journal.conditions: Slight Chance T-storms then Showers Likely with a high of 83°F dropping to 63°F overnight.
journal.observations: Seedlings appear vigorous, upright, and expanding with bright green true leaves forming throughout the cluster. No new chewing damage is visible and leaf texture is healthy. Soil remains wet from overnight moisture and incoming rain, with surface saturation consistent with the weather pattern. The pH has risen slightly and EC has increased as moisture shifts, both normal trends during early vegetative growth.
journal.actions: Do not water today. Allow natural rainfall and high humidity to maintain moisture. No pest control or amendments are needed at this time.
journal.next_steps: Recheck moisture tomorrow once showers pass. Monitor for continued true leaf expansion and stable color. Avoid thinning until seedlings develop larger, more defined foliage.

photos.caption: Digital probe screenshot showing today's Jalapeño soil readings.
Jalapeño seedlings showing upright growth, bright green leaves, and early true leaf development.
Side angle of the Jalapeño cluster showing healthy leaf posture and moist soil from recent rain.
Additional view of the Jalapeño seedlings showing consistent color and early vegetative growth.

journal.conditions: Patchy morning fog, then sunny with a high near 86°F. Light south wind 5–8 mph. Evening partly cloudy with a low around 66°F. Patchy fog expected overnight.
journal.observation: Seedlings remain healthy, upright, and vigorously growing. Cotyledons show no new chewing damage compared to prior photos, indicating that pest activity has stopped following the 12/04 spinosad treatment. Moisture is very high due to recent watering and calm, foggy conditions, and soil appears evenly saturated. No signs of wilt, mold, or stress are present.
journal.actions: Do not water today. No pest treatment required, as no new chew holes are visible and prior damage has not progressed.
journal.next_steps: Check moisture again tomorrow late morning. Monitor for the emergence of the first true leaf pair within the next several days. Only reapply spinosad if new holes appear within 5–7 days.

photos.caption: Digital probe screenshot showing high moisture levels and stable seedling environment.
Jalapeño seedlings with no new chewing damage and healthy upright posture.

journal.conditions: Mostly sunny with a high of 84°F dropping to 64°F overnight.
journal.observation: Seedlings remain upright and vigorous but now exhibit multiple new pin-holes across cotyledons. Damage is consistent with active flea beetle or small chewing insect activity. No signs of disease or nutrient stress. Soil is well-hydrated following a necessary watering earlier in the afternoon due to rapid drying in Florida sun.
journal.actions: Apply a light, targeted mist of Captain Jack's Deadbug (spinosad) at dusk. Focus on tops and bottoms of leaves and the soil surface around stems. Do not use neem oil. No additional watering needed today.
journal.next_steps: Check seedlings tomorrow morning for any new holes. Evaluate moisture level and apply the next watering based on probe readings. If new damage appears, consider a follow-up spinosad treatment in 5–7 days.
follow_up: [4:45 PM] Observed numerous new pin-holes on cotyledons indicating active pest feeding.

photos.caption: Digital probe screenshot showing today's soil readings after necessary watering.
Seedlings with scattered pin-hole chewing damage on cotyledons, consistent with flea beetle activity.

journal: [5:35 PM] Applied Captain Jack's Deadbug as instructed, using a light mist over leaves (top and underside) and soil surface.

journal.conditions: Mostly sunny with a high of 82°F dropping to 62°F overnight.
journal.observation: Seedlings remain upright, vigorous, and uniformly green. Cotyledons show the lifted, forward-tilting posture associated with imminent true leaf emergence. Chewing damage from yesterday appears unchanged with no new holes or signs of active pests. Soil surface is lightly crusted from sun but still evenly hydrated beneath.
journal.actions: No watering today. Pest control not required at this time as no new damage is observed.
journal.next_steps: Recheck moisture tomorrow morning; watering will likely be needed within 24 hours if drying continues. Monitor closely for first true leaf emergence.

photos.caption: Digital probe screenshot showing today's Jalapeño soil readings.
Jalapeño seedlings showing upright growth and stable cotyledons with no new pest damage.

journal.conditions: Mostly cloudy with a high of 84°F dropping to 67°F overnight; wind gusts up to 19 mph.
journal.observation: Seedlings remain healthy and upright with cotyledons fully extended, though new chewing damage is visible on one leaf. Moisture is high but stable under cloudy conditions, and wind gusts have not caused structural stress. No signs of disease or overwatering are present.
journal.actions: Do not water today. Inspect seedlings closely for hidden caterpillars or larvae. Apply a light, targeted mist of Captain Jack's Deadbug at dusk if additional chewing appears.
journal.next_steps: Monitor seedling cluster tomorrow for new holes or expanding damage. Check for first true leaf emergence as upward growth continues.
follow_up: [12:02 PM] Noticed fresh chewing damage on cotyledon and inspected seedlings for hidden pests.

photos.caption: Digital probe screenshot showing today's Jalapeño soil readings.
Jalapeño seedlings with healthy upright cotyledons and a visible chewing hole on one leaf.

journal.conditions: Cloudy with a high of 72°F dropping to 57°F overnight; clear conditions expected around 6 PM.
journal.observation: Seedlings remain upright and healthy with cotyledons that are beginning the subtle lift that precedes first true leaf formation. Soil is evenly moist from recent rain and the surface texture is stable with no signs of compaction or pooling. The cooler temperatures and elevated pH are well within a safe range for early growth.
journal.actions: Do not water today. Allow natural drying through the afternoon and evening.
journal.next_steps: Recheck moisture and seedling posture tomorrow as temperatures rise slightly. Watch closely for the first true leaves.

photos.caption: Digital probe screenshot showing today's Jalapeño soil readings.
Jalapeño seedlings showing healthy upright cotyledons with soil evenly moist after recent rain.

journal.conditions: Cloudy with a high of 81°F dropping to 65°F overnight; rain expected around 6 PM.
journal.observation: Seedlings remain healthy and upright with consistent green cotyledons and no signs of damping-off. Soil is moderately moist and newly added soil around the probe holes has been leveled without stressing the plants. Leaves have small soil flecks from adjustments, but overall growth posture is stable.
journal.actions: Apply a very light rinse to clean soil from the leaves and settle the added soil. Do not perform a full watering due to expected evening rain.
journal.next_steps: Allow rain to provide deeper hydration later today. Recheck moisture and seedling posture tomorrow and ensure soil remains evenly settled.

photos.caption: Digital probe screenshot showing today's Jalapeño soil readings.
Cluster of Jalapeño seedlings showing upright cotyledons and newly leveled soil surface.
Wider view of planter showing seedling cluster and soil condition prior to expected rain.

journal.conditions: Mostly cloudy with a high of 84°F dropping to 67°F overnight; thunderstorms expected around 4 PM.
journal.observation: Seedlings are vigorous with fully expanded cotyledons and upright stems. Soil was already well hydrated before the light rain, and moisture levels are expected to rise further as storms develop later today. No signs of foliar stress or damping-off are present.
journal.actions: Do not water today. Allow natural rainfall to handle moisture. Avoid disturbing the seedling cluster and monitor for any pooling after thunderstorms.
journal.next_steps: Check moisture and surface conditions after storms pass. Reassess hydration needs tomorrow once the soil has time to settle.

photos.caption: Digital probe screenshot showing today’s Jalapeño soil readings.
Jalapeño seedlings showing healthy upright growth with moist soil prior to incoming storms.

journal.conditions: Partly cloudy with a high of 81°F dropping to 61°F overnight.
journal.observation: Seedlings appear healthy with elongated cotyledons and upright early stems. Soil is visibly dry and the low moisture reading confirms that the planter is nearing the lower threshold for young seedlings. No signs of damping-off or foliar stress are present.
journal.actions: No corrective action needed beyond today's light shower. Avoid disturbing seedlings and maintain steady light exposure.
journal.next_steps: Recheck moisture and general seedling posture tomorrow. Monitor for the first signs of true leaf formation as seedlings stabilize.
follow_up: [10:57 AM] Gave it a light shower

photos.caption: Digital probe screenshot showing today’s Jalapeño soil readings.
Jalapeño seedlings showing expanded cotyledons and dry soil surface under morning sun.

journal.conditions: Sunny with a high of 84°F dropping to 63°F overnight.
journal.observation: Multiple new sprouts have emerged since yesterday, indicating strong germination success within the expected window. Seedlings appear healthy, upright, and evenly colored with no signs of damping-off or stress. Soil pH has risen slightly from yesterday’s low and remains mildly acidic but non-harmful. EC and salts have increased as soil temperature climbed, reflecting normal ion mobility. Moisture remains in an ideal range for early seedlings, and the soil surface is aerated with no fungal growth.
journal.actions: No watering needed. Do not add lime or fertilizer. Maintain sunlight exposure and avoid disturbing the dense cluster of emerging seedlings.
journal.next_steps: Monitor seedlings over the next 24–48 hours for cotyledon expansion. Recheck moisture and pH tomorrow. Begin watching for early stem lengthening as sprouts stabilize.

photos.caption: Digital probe screenshot showing today’s Jalapeño soil readings.
Multiple new Jalapeño sprouts emerging around the support pole in the left section of the pepper window box.

journal.conditions: Mostly cloudy with a high of 84°F dropping to 67°F overnight.
journal.observation: Two sprouts have emerged on either side of the support pole, marking successful germination and entry into the seedling emergence stage. Soil moisture continues to decline steadily and remains appropriate for early seedlings. The sharp drop in pH and EC reflects cooler morning temperatures, reduced ion mobility, and natural microbial shifts during sprout emergence. Surface lime remains in patches but is not impeding growth. Soil appears loose and well-aerated with no signs of damping-off or fungal growth.
journal.actions: No watering required today. Do not add lime or fertilizer. Maintain sunlight exposure and avoid disturbing the cotyledons as they open fully.
journal.next_steps: Monitor sprouts over the next 24–48 hours for cotyledon expansion. Recheck moisture and pH tomorrow. Begin watching for early signs of stem elongation and ensure the surface stays lightly aerated.

photos.caption: Digital probe screenshot showing today’s soil readings for the Jalapeño.
Two newly emerged Jalapeño sprouts visible near the support pole with lime residue on the soil surface.

journal.conditions: Sunny with a high of 84°F dropping to 60°F overnight.
journal.observations: Moisture has continued its steady decline from the oversaturation event and is now within an appropriate upper range for germination. pH has risen consistently over multiple days and is now mildly acidic but stable, aided by remaining lime dissolving at the surface. Soil temperature is excellent for germination and surface texture appears loose, aerated, and free of fungal growth. No sprout is visible yet, consistent with the early germination window.
journal.actions: No watering required. Do not add lime or fertilizer. Maintain planter in full sun and allow natural drying.
journal.next_steps: Recheck moisture, pH, and temperature within 24–48 hours. Watch for the first signs of seedling emergence during the current germination window.

photos.caption: Jalapeño planter surface showing lime residue and improving soil structure.

journal.conditions: Mostly sunny with a high of 83°F dropping to 64°F overnight.
journal.observations: Soil moisture remains elevated but continues to improve after the oversaturation event. pH shows slight upward correction but remains acidic. No sprouts are visible. Soil texture appears loose with scattered lime on the surface. Warm soil temperature supports germination.
journal.actions: No watering required. Do not add lime or fertilizer. Allow soil to dry naturally in full sun.
journal.next_steps: Recheck moisture and pH within 24–48 hours. Maintain sunlight and avoid watering until moisture decreases.

photos.caption: Jalapeño planter showing surface lime distribution and soil condition.

journal.conditions: Mostly sunny with a high around 82–85°F dropping to 64°F overnight.
journal.observations: Soil remained heavily saturated following previous watering, with pH still strongly acidic. Lime was partially dissolved and uneven across the surface. No sprouts observed and no signs of pests or mold.
journal.actions: No watering required. Do not add lime or fertilizer. Allow soil to dry in sun.
journal.next_steps: Recheck soil moisture and pH within 24–48 hours. Allow continued drying before further adjustments.
follow_up: [2:52 PM] Planter was heavily watered accidentally by grandson; soil became fully saturated and most remaining lime dissolved. No additional lime will be added; allow planter to dry naturally.

photos.caption: Morning planter photo showing surface lime and soil condition.
Afternoon follow-up showing oversaturated soil after accidental watering.

journal.conditions: Partly cloudy with a high of 82°F dropping to 65°F overnight.
journal.observations: Soil was still wet but drying from previous watering. pH showed modest improvement. No sprouting visible. Surface lime remained in patches and soil texture appeared loose.
journal.actions: No watering needed. Do not add lime or fertilizer. Allow continued drying.
journal.next_steps: Recheck pH and moisture within 24–48 hours.

photos.caption: Pepper box showing lime distribution across Scotch Bonnet, Orange Cal Wonder, and Jalapeño sections.

journal.conditions: Mostly sunny with a high of 81°F dropping to 61°F overnight.
journal.observations: Soil was wet but not waterlogged, with pH strongly acidic following earlier adjustments. No sprouting present. Soil surface intact with scattered lime and good sunlight exposure.
journal.actions: Apply 2 teaspoons of dolomitic lime as a surface top-dress. Do not water until the surface dries. No fertilizer.
journal.next_steps: Recheck moisture and pH within 24–48 hours.

photos.caption: Jalapeño planter section showing initial lime application.
